results.title: Acropolis Now
results.credit_line:
Courtesy Crawford DVD

Acropolis Now is held in the collection of the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: In the 1980s, roles for Greek actors were limited, so they created their own - first the stage show Wogs out of Work (1987), and then the sitcom Acropolis Now, one of the first TV shows to bring much-needed diversity to Australian screens.

constellations_primary.name: Culture, food and family
constellations_primary.description: Food as a link to culture and family.

constellations_other.name: Australian TV in the 1980s
constellations_other.description: Australian television in the 80s really began to find its footing with mainstream hits becoming landmarks of the industry.

constellations_other.name: Ana Kokkinos
constellations_other.description: The films and TV works of Ana Kokkinos often explore the experiences of second-generation Australians, queer identities and class. Since beginning her career in the early 90s, those stories have started to appear more frequently on Australian screens.

results.description:
After World War II, Greek cinema circuits spread across Australia and were an epicentre of Greek community, language and culture that influenced many future filmmakers, such as Ana Kokkinos.

In the 1980s, roles for Greek actors were limited, so they created their own - first the stage show Wogs out of Work (1987), and then the sitcom Acropolis Now, one of the first TV shows to bring much-needed diversity to Australian screens. Besides the perfectly timed one-liners and unforgettable characters like Jim (Nick Giannopoulos) and Effie (Mary Coustas), it gave second-generation Greek Australians control of how they were portrayed - and what was acceptable to laugh at - and defied racial stereotypes that non-Greek actors, like The Comedy Company‘s Con the Fruiterer (Mark Mitchell), perpetuated on Australian TV.
description_for_label:
After World War II, Greek cinema circuits spread across Australia and were an epicentre of Greek community, language and culture that influenced many future filmmakers, such as Ana Kokkinos.

In the 1980s, roles for Greek actors were limited, so they created their own - first the stage show Wogs out of Work (1987), and then the sitcom Acropolis Now, one of the first TV shows to bring much-needed diversity to Australian screens. Besides the perfectly timed one-liners and unforgettable characters like Jim (Nick Giannopoulos) and Effie (Mary Coustas), it gave second-generation Greek Australians control of how they were portrayed - and what was acceptable to laugh at - and defied racial stereotypes that non-Greek actors, like The Comedy Company‘s Con the Fruiterer (Mark Mitchell), perpetuated on Australian TV.
results.credit_line_for_label:
Courtesy Crawford DVD

Acropolis Now is held in the collection of the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia

results.title: Acquiring a taste for Raffaella
results.creator_credit: AFTRS, Fotini Manikakis and Sandra Lepore
results.brief_description: The onset of menstruation leads to a curious mix of events when Raffaella shares the news with her traditional Italian Aunt. Together they make some special Italian love biscuits, “biscotti di amore”, with a secret ingredient intimately linked with Raffaella’s menarche. When the object of her affections tastes the love biscuits, surprisingly, he asks for the recipe.

results.title: Acoustic behaviour of the grey kangaroo
results.creator_credit: Australian National University and Ross Christopher
results.brief_description: Looks at the work done at the Acoustic Laboratory of the research School of Biological Sciences at the Australian National University on senses in kangaroos. Shows the environment of the kangaroo and how its hearing is used in cooperation with its eyes for scanning.

results.title: acousma
results.brief_description: It uses as its basis recordings of the electrical activity occuring within my brain during unconsciousness, to create a unique sound composition, a kind of audio representation of my dreams during sleep. This we realised through the use of software to systematically create audio transcriptions of both my EEG (electroencephalography) wave-traces and MRI images into sound, subsequently giving my unconscious mind a voice. The visual element of the piece consists of the entire sequence of MRI scans which were used in creating the soundtrack. These I animated in order that the viewer be taken on a highly unorthodox journey through the human head, as part of the experience

results.title: Acne...it's not your fault
results.brief_description: Outlines the various types of acne suffered by adolescents ranging from a few spots to severe inflamation and indicates the treatment required for each of these stages of acne severity. Stresses that bad acne needs treatment by a medical practitioner.

results.title: acmipark
results.material_description: software, computers, monitors, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
acmipark is multiplayer virtual world. Created by selectparks (artists Julian Oliver, Chad Chatterton, and Andrea Blundell), it was designed to extend the physical spaces of the Australian Centre for the Moving Image (ACMI) at Melbourne’s Federation Square into the realms of virtual space. It was produced using a game engine as its base, and worked up from the real architectural designs produced for Federation Square by Lab Architecture Studio.

Designed as a soundpark, it is a musical instrument which can be played collectively, and, like Federation Square itself, it was envisaged as a kind of public space waiting for a community to define its meaning.

It was conceived as an experiment in the design of a virtual public space. It is an embodiment of the idea that we are moving our public space into the realm of the virtual. By using a model of a real world public space combined with the collaborative possibilities of the soundpark and the kinaesthetic pleasures of moving through a beautiful virtual place, selectparks hoped to build upon traditional concepts of ‘public’ places.

[Source: Helen Stuckey, 2006 https://firstmonday.org/ojs/index.php/fm/article/view/1561/1476 last accessed 20/10/2020]
